text: in uh December of 2010 I was doing a
speaking tour of the Middle East and I
had a day off in Qatar and I decided
that I wanted to go dun blasting because
the brochure in the hotel said that your
guide will drive you over 100t sand
Cliffs at 70 mph but my favorite part of
the road sure was it it said and then he
will help keep you alive overnight in
the
desert and I said that sounds confident
enough for me let's do that so I wander
out at 7 o'clock in the morning and I
meet my guide and it's this man right
here now this is the only time
throughout the entire course of the day
that he was not smiling because he said
that the ladies like it when you look
intense in
photographs and as I walk towards this
guy he jumps out of the car and he
throws his hands he goes Mr Dudley
welcome to mustafa's Grand
Adventure I am
Mustafa and I wanted to match his energy
so I idiotically went with this Mustafa
like The Lion
King and he like dead pan looks at me
and goes that's
muasa I said apparently he's not going
to try that hard to keep me alive in the
desert right but then he gets his big
grit he's like I'm kidding I'm kidding
hop in and this guy starts to talk and
he starts to talk about what we're going
to learn from the desert he starts to
talk talk about all he knows about
Canada this man is just pouring energy
out and this is 7:00 in the morning and
this is 1 hour nonstop and we're an hour
outside the city and finally I just go
Mustafa man where do you get your energy
you were the most upbeat dude that I
have ever been with and he looks at me
and he goes with this huge smile and
says it's my first
day now I'm well aware that everyone has
to start
somewhere but when there are 100 foot
Cliffs involved I would rather not be in
the car with the Newbie right and I
guess I look terrified and he goes don't
worry don't worry it's always my first
day and I said what do you mean he goes
well think about it on your first day
you dress your best you show up early
you really really try to impress your
boss you're incredibly nice to your
co-workers you are never more committed
to your job than you are on your first
day as a matter of fact you are never
more convinced that this is going to be
the greatest job that you have ever had
than you are on your first day as soon
as your second day starts all of that
starts to stop being being quite so true
he said 13 years ago I started this job
and I loved it and I knew I was going to
love it and so I decided 13 years ago
that I would never have a second day of
work so it has been my first day for 13
years and I was so inspired by that way
of looking at life and work but was
really weird is that just as quickly I
kind of got depressed because this was
right after I had quit my job and I had
loved my job but there had been this
really intense interpersonal conflict
that had gone on for quite a while and
finally made me feel like I had to go
and when I heard him talk about how much
he loved his job I couldn't help but
start to think about everything that I
felt like I'd been pushed away from in
mind everything that I'd helped to build
and then I'd had to say goodbye to and
everything that seemed to be like torn
apart and I started to think about the
person that I held responsible for it
and I got really quiet and he thought
that he'd insulted me and he said Drew
I'm so sorry did I say something wrong
and I said no Mustafa and then I
basically tell this complete stranger an
incredibly personal story of my life
conflict and he gets really quiet and
finally says Drew this person that
you're talking about they are so far
away they are so far away that it is
night where they are and it is day where
you are but you're letting them make it
night where you are you are letting them
wreck mustafa's Grand
Adventure and they're not even here and
what's worse you're acting like it's
their fault and I kind of got annoyed I
was like well it is their fault I just
told you the story and he goes no with
respect Drew it's your fault because
you're letting them live rent free in
your head he says think about it think
about a landlord a landlord will allow
people to use their property but they
charge rent to make sure they get
something valuable in return to protect
their investment he said your head and
your heart are the most valuable pieces
of property that you own and if you're
going to let people use them you would
better make sure that you get something
valuable in return all that this person
brings you is anger and bitterness and
sadness and none of those things are
valuable to you but when you accept
anger and bitterness and sadness in
return for access to your head in your
heart you were basically letting someone
live there rentree and he said drew the
landlord sets the rent all right you're
the landlord you're not allowed to be
angry when all you get paid is what you
asked for and this guy was dropping
knowledge like that on me for 18 hours
straight it was like
going honestly it was like going Dune
blasting with
Yoda
but we've and we've talked a lot about
the power of human connection today but
when I think about what Mustafa said
what I'm reminded of is that not
everything to which we are connected
brings us value and unfortunately some
of the most powerful connections that we
allow ourselves to forge can actually be
among our most limiting and I was the
producer of a musical project once and
one of the songs that was submitted had
this set of lyrics that I've always
remembered and they said there's a
difference between grounded and run into
the ground some things keep you rooted
and some just weigh you down and and you
have to decide what youd rather keep
around and I think that the ability to
take a look at the connections in our
lives and honestly ask ourselves which
of these things are keeping us rooted
and which of these things are weighing
us down that's an incredibly valuable
skill to have in order to get the most
out of a life that's going to knock us
around sometimes because there are
things that live rentree in our heads
and it's not always people it's also
failures it's also losses and it's also
these ideas that somewhere along the way
we pick them up and they start to limit
us and there's one particular idea
that's been living rentree in way too
many young people's heads and it's kind
of become my passion to go after it and
for me it started when when I was
working with a group of University
students in a workshop and I asked what
I thought was a completely innocuous
question and I'm going to ask it to some
unfortunate person in the front row here
as well you have won congratulations are
you ready you look so excited right now
so let me ask you the question I asked
that day why do you
matter and that look of absolute terror
is exactly what happened and I said okay
and then I asked somebody else in the
crowd why do you matter and I got that
same look of confusion and and sort of
fear and I started Ed to ask that
question and I've asked it to hundreds
of University and college students all
around the world and watching them
struggle to answer it has made me
realize that there is an idea that is
living rentree in your head and that is
that you are somehow training to matter
right now and that one day when you get
good enough marks from good enough
schools and you make enough money from
prestigious enough jobs then all of the
sudden then you will be ready to matter
and everything that we're doing in the
meantime is some sort of training
session and I think we' have got to
evict this idea that the biggest impact
you're going to have on the world is
going to come to down the pipe later on
we've got to evict this idea that this
is some sort of training to matter you
matter right now and we've also got to
ask ourselves is this really can we
really call it an education when the
best the brightest the smartest and the
most well-educated young people in our
countries freak out because no one's
ever asked them why do you matter before
because you do when I was 19 years old
my parents let me throw the end of high
school party like the one that's been in
every teen comedy movie ever and partway
through the party I was leaning back
against the cottage and I saw two of my
friends who were a couple and they were
all snuggled up watching the sun go down
and I snapped a photograph of it and
then I leaned back against the cottage
and got all bitter and I turned to my
buddy Scott who was sitting next to me
and I said Scott you know it sucks that
I don't have somebody like that you know
it really sucks I I'm so tired of always
being alone and Scotty who is that
friend who's the athlete and musician
the perfect balance of left brain right
brain we've all got Scotty looks at me
and goes Drew for a guy who's got
everything going for him all I ever hear
from you is about what you don't have
and I was not yet at that point in my
life where I want friends who tell me
what I need to hear as opposed to what I
want to
hear so I pushed back and I said I don't
have everything going for me you know
all I have is pressure all I have as
people telling me make sure you keep
getting those amazing marks and make
sure that you live up to your potential
all I feel like I have is an opportunity
to disappoint everyone all I feel is
like I have an opportunity to be a
failure in front of everybody who
believes in me and Scott looked at me
for what seemed like a really long time
and then he said Drew you've got to give
your friends more credit he says we
don't care about you because of the guy
that you might be one day we care about
you because of the guy that you are now
I think you have to start doing the same
thing and that is a piece of advice that
has stuck with me for my entire life
never diminish the person that you are
in the name of this person that you
think you're going to become one day and
you know what give your friends more
credit because they're going to forgive
you and the really true friends I've
discovered as you get older the true
true friends in your life they are the
ones who judge you based on the person
they know you are on an average Tuesday
afternoon not the person we are
sometimes on our worst Saturday
nights but unfortunately uh only a few
weeks after Scott gave me that advice uh
he and my other friend Tim were actually
killed in a car accident just outside of
my hometown and Scotty was 18 years old
and that was 16 years ago and I'm
talking about what he taught me on a
stage at a Ted event 16 years later
because he mattered and so do you guys
and after I said goodbye to Scott I went
off to University and I met this amazing
guy not to be stereotypical Canadian but
there he is in the hockey
uniform and his name was Jason Abraham
and Jason was the one of the senior
staff members at the bar that I ended up
working at and everybody loved this guy
and he was one of the coolest guys on
campus and I had wanted to be cool since
I was old enough to know that I
wasn't so like four
and so one night after work I said to
Jason man like how do you connect so
easily to people like how is it that
people seem so drawn to you and he said
you know what I just try to keep it
simple I think that your life is better
the fewer times you put yourself in a
position where you might feel forced to
say I'm sorry and if you want to pull
unnecessary I'm sorries out of your life
the easiest way to do it is this every
time you talk about somebody act as if
they are standing directly behind you
your life just gets easier
every time you talk about somebody act
as if they're standing directly behind
you is maybe the best life advice I have
ever been given that I find a way to
ignore on an almost daily basis but
that's how this guy talked and that's
how this guy lived and unfortunately
just a few weeks after he gave me that
advice uh Jason was diagnosed with
abdominal cancer and within five weeks
he was gone and Jason Abraham was 23
years old and I stand on stages all over
the world and I talk about what he
taught me because he mattered I'm 36
years old and I have been to six of my
friends weddings and I've been to 15 of
their funerals and I could do a full
talk on what every single one of those
individuals taught me and that has made
my life better and not one of them lived
to see their 24th birthday but they
mattered and I think that we have to
evict this idea from our minds that
impact and the ability to make an impact
is in any way shape or form related to
how old you are or how well you do in
school or how much money that you're
going to make because honestly your
ability to turn out and matter to
someone and have them talk about what
you taught them is absolutely
immeasurable and I love talking about
the the the lessons that my friends
taught me because that's how I I let go
of their loss and I I talk about them in
a lot of different places about two
years ago I was talking about Scotty I
was talking about Jason and at the end
of the presentation this young woman
walked up to me and she said Drew I I
really liked your presentation but I
feel bad for all the pain that you've
had in your life and then she told me
her story and it was filled with so much
more courage and so many more challenges
and so much more pain and loss than mine
was that I looked at her and I said how
in the world can you tell me that you
feel bad for the pain I've had in my
life when you're so obviously Dwarfs
Mine and she looked at me and she said
Drew I have discovered that there is no
Universal measuring unit for pain hurt
just hurts so comparing it is pointless
but I have discovered that only hurt
people hurt others and so if I want to
be the type of person I want to be I've
got to let go of the things that hurt me
so that I don't end up hurting the
people I care about only hurt people
hurt others honestly that is one of
those things that you know that it's
true when you hear it but the more that
I've lived with it in my life the more
powerful it has become because what it
has come to me to me is that leaders
have to heal we have got to let go and
disconnect from the things that have
hurt us otherwise we will carry those
things around with us and one day we
will use them as a weapon against the
people that we care about the most the
fact is that leaders have to forgive the
problem is I think that we want to win
like we carry around these conflicts
with us and we know they're sucking
value out of our lives but we want to
win we don't want anybody out there
thinking that they beat us anybody
thinking they got one over on us we know
that we should let them go but we're not
willing to do so until somebody
acknowledges that we were right and that
we won and I want to let you know the
most extraordinary people that I've
worked with in my life they could not
care less about winning what they care
about is succeeding and sometimes the
only true way to get into success is to
let go of this idea that we have to win
I lost way too many friends in ways that
I cannot control to not tell every
audience who will listen that if you can
save a relationship personal family
romantic by simply saying I'm sorry or
hearing I'm sorry please do it because
there is absolutely no worst feeling in
the world that going to the funeral of
somebody that you cared about
desperately and the last thing you said
to them was terrible and I think
leadership means going to bed every
single night and knowing that that can't
possibly be true but I know that almost
everybody in this room has somebody
somebody that you wish was still in your
life and the only reason that they're
not that you can't text them or call
them or share things with them is
because you either will not say I'm
sorry or hear I'm sorry guys do it there
is no weakness in forgiveness and I
honestly believe that sometimes
leadership begins where forgiveness
begins but I know that it's not just
that easy like I I recognize that you
can't just forgive and snap your fingers
I mean I don't do it I know that I'm
still carrying things with me and I
don't expect us all to be able to walk
out here today and immediately forgive
everyone who's ever hurt us or let go of
any everything that's ever made us feel
like less than we are but what I do
think we have to do is we have to be
willing to ask the question every day
honestly what is living rentree in my
head and am I ready to let it go because
the answer might not be yes today and it
might not be yes tomorrow and it may not
be yes for a long long time but I
honestly believe that any question that
is asked every day is going to get
answered sooner than one that is only
asked once a week or once a month or
once a year or we never ask at all
because we're afraid of the answer
because honestly guys I think that
leadership isn't knowing all the answers
leadership is being willing to keep
asking the unanswered questions in our
lives over and over again until we're
ready to hear the answer because there
are things living rentree in our lives
but guess what we're the landlord the
landlord sets the rent and I think when
it comes to our head and our heart that
it's time to jack up the prices a little
bit guys thank you so very much for
letting me share that with you today all
right peace thank you very much
